html:
3.19.18  3:17 pm   As much as I love jazz, I have never been able to "acquire" a taste for overly dissonant parts that somehow become recognied by music buffs as genius.

     So I wholeharedtly agree with your approach of focusing on the way music "sounds", but you seem to have an excellent grasp of theory,

      and this is why so many of your fans ask for tips on studying, yet you are often dismissive of such questions.

      I just wanted to let you know that you're a hero among aspiring musicians, and we just want to know if you have any tips on how to learn all the rules, even if it means we have to break them every now and then.

3.18.18  2:58 pm   I'm working on this weird tune, kind of inspired by schoenberg, stravinsky, horror film scores and all that weird stuff... and it's very slow with no clear beat to latch on to (rubato, I think that's called). I have the main part down, but I'm trying to overdub other instruments (all using the keyboard) and it's tricky. I'm having a real hard time adding parts on top because there's no defined rhythm to use as reference. I tried giving it a set tempo, just really slow, and figuring out what the rhythm could be.. but when I do that, it sounds more rigid and stiff and kind of changes the vibe of the thing. Have you ever recorded anything that had multiple tracks, but no defined beat or rhythm?
3.18.18  2:14 pm   where do trees come from

3.18.18  1:47 pm   m7b5 and half-diminished are the same thing, right?

     Are there certain situations where it would make more sense to call it one name over the other, or does it not really matter?

3.18.18  1:45 pm   Hi, Bill. Yesterday I went for a spontaneous walk around my neighborhood (which is a bit strange for me since I generally just stay inside all day) and I found out that there is a graveyard within about twenty minutes of my house. Do you have any idea why people think graveyards are scary?

     It felt pretty peaceful to me. Also, do you have any opinions on graveyards?

sure
